message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest preeclampsia with severe features, which can lead to seizures (eclampsia). IV magnesium sulfate and diazepam are used to prevent seizures, and Labetalol is a medication that affects both alpha and beta receptors and is used to control hypertension in pregnant women with preeclampsia. The other options only affect beta receptors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of preeclampsia, which includes hypertension, proteinuria, and edema. Treatment includes magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures, diazepam to control blood pressure, and a medication that affects both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors to control blood pressure. Labetalol can block both alpha and beta receptors and is commonly used in the treatment of preeclampsia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with preeclampsia, and the medication that affects both alpha and beta receptors is Labetalol. It can lower blood pressure and help prevent seizures in patients with preeclampsia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with preeclampsia, which can cause hypertension, proteinuria, and edema. Treatment includes IV magnesium sulfate, diazepam, and a medication that affects both α- and β-adrenergic receptors to control blood pressure, and among the options, only labetalol fits this description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of preeclampsia, including hypertension, edema, and proteinuria. Magnesium sulfate is given for seizure prevention, and diazepam is given for anxiety. Labetalol, which affects both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, is the most appropriate medication for treating hypertension in this case. Metoprolol and esmolol are more cardioselective and may not be as effective in managing hypertension in this patient with preeclampsia. Pindolol has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and is not typically used to treat hypertension in preeclampsia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms consistent with preeclampsia, including hypertension, proteinuria, and edema. IV magnesium sulfate is used to prevent seizures, while diazepam is used to control agitation. Labetalol, which affects both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, is the medication of choice for hypertension in pregnant women with preeclampsia as it has been shown to be safe for both the mother and the fetus. Metoprolol affects only beta receptors, while esmolol and pindolol have more specific effects on heart rate and contractility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest preeclampsia, which can lead to eclampsia and maternal and fetal mortality. Treatment includes IV magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures, diazepam for sedation, and antihypertensives like labetalol, which affects both a- and ß-adrenergic receptors. Metoprolol, esmolol, and pindolol only affect ß-adrenergic receptors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of preeclampsia and is immediately started on IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Labetalol is a medication that affects both a- and ß-adrenergic receptors and is used in the treatment of hypertension in preeclampsia. Metoprolol and esmolol only affect ß-adrenergic receptors and pindolol affects both a- and ß-adrenergic receptors, but is not commonly used to treat hypertension in preeclampsia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest preeclampsia with severe features, which can cause maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. IV magnesium sulfate and diazepam are used to prevent seizures. Labetalol, which affects both alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors, is used for hypertensive emergency in pregnancy. Metoprolol, esmolol, and pindolol are beta-blockers, which are contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of fetal growth restriction and neonatal hypoglycemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs of preeclampsia, including hypertension, proteinuria, and edema. Magnesium sulfate and diazepam are given to prevent seizures, while a medication that affects both a- and ß-adrenergic receptors is given to control blood pressure. Among the options, only labetalol fits this description.
